strengths.detail: The organization directs <cite id="2">1.0% of its expenses</cite> toward its core programs, ensuring that donor funds are used entirely for mission-related activities.
MWF reports spending <cite id="1">$0.00 per $1 raised</cite>, indicating that it does not currently incur significant professional fundraising costs.
The foundation has demonstrated strong momentum with a <cite id="2">3-year revenue CAGR of 49.6%</cite>, growing from approximately $99,778 in 2021 to over $223,000 in 2023.

strengths_deep_dive: The Muslim Wellness Foundation's primary strength lies in its niche focus on the intersection of faith and mental health. By providing <cite id="3">Mental Health First Aid trainings</cite> tailored for Muslim contexts, they address a critical gap in domestic social services. Their financial model is currently characterized by a <cite id="2">100.0% program expense ratio</cite>, which is significantly higher than the <cite id="1">peer program ratio median of 82.6%</cite> for domestic poverty and healthcare organizations. This efficiency is bolstered by the fact that the organization <cite id="2">reported $223,205 in contributions</cite> without incurring traditional fundraising overhead, allowing for a direct flow of resources into community advocacy and the <cite id="4">Black Muslim Psychology Conference</cite>.
rich_narrative.summary: The Muslim Wellness Foundation (MWF) is a specialized nonprofit organization dedicated to <cite id="3">promoting healing and emotional well-being</cite> within the American Muslim community. Operating with a focus on capacity building and community-based initiatives, the organization reported <cite id="2">total revenue of $223,205</cite> in the 2023 tax year. MWF distinguishes itself through culturally specific mental health advocacy, most notably through its <cite id="4">Black Muslim Psychology Conference (BMPC)</cite> and <cite id="3">Mental Health First Aid (MHFA) trainings</cite>. Despite its relatively small scale, the organization demonstrates high financial efficiency in its service delivery, reporting a <cite id="2">100.0% program expense ratio</cite>, meaning all reported functional expenses were directed toward its mission-driven activities. Furthermore, the organization maintains <cite id="1">high fundraising efficiency</cite>, spending $0.00 to raise every $1 in contribution revenue. While the foundation has seen significant growth, with a <cite id="2">3-year revenue CAGR of 49.6%</cite>, it remains in an emerging stage with <cite id="1">0.2 months of working capital</cite>, indicating a lean operational model that relies heavily on consistent annual support to maintain its specialized community programming.
